objectives.description: Recognize key terms and concepts related to home buying, mortgages, and the homeownership process from start to finish.
Analyze different types of mortgages and their requirements, advantages, and ideal buyer profiles to make informed decisions.
Determine the true costs of homeownership‚Äîupfront, ongoing, and hidden expenses‚Äîbeyond just the purchase price.
Assess whether homeownership aligns with your financial goals, lifestyle, and timeline for readiness.

terms.definition: A loan specifically for purchasing real estate, where the property itself serves as collateral for the lender.
terms.example: 15-year or 30-year repayment periods; fixed or adjustable interest rates

terms.definition: Initial upfront payment toward the purchase price, typically 3-20% of the home's value.
terms.example: A $300K home with 10% down = $30,000 down payment, $270K mortgage

terms.definition: Private Mortgage Insurance‚Äîrequired when down payment is less than 20%, protecting the lender if you default.
terms.example: Adds 0.5-1% of loan annually; can be removed once you reach 20% equity

terms.definition: The difference between your home's market value and what you still owe‚Äîyour ownership stake.
terms.example: Home worth $350K, mortgage balance $250K = $100K equity (your wealth)

layoutData.title: 6 Steps from Preparation to Keys in Hand
paragraphs: Purchasing a home typically takes 2-3 months from offer to closing‚Äîbut preparation starts 6-12 months earlier.
bulletPoints: 1. Financial Prep (6-12 mo): Improve credit, save for down payment, reduce debt
2. Get Pre-Approved: Submit documents to lenders, know your budget
3. House Hunting: Work with agent, tour homes, research neighborhoods
4. Make an Offer: Submit offer with contingencies, negotiate terms
5. Inspection & Appraisal: Verify condition and value, negotiate repairs
6. Closing: Sign documents, pay closing costs, get keys!

leftPanel.title: Finding the Right Loan for You
paragraphs: Different mortgage programs exist to accommodate various financial situations. Your options depend on credit score, down payment savings, and eligibility.
Conventional Loans: Most common, 3-20% down, 620+ credit score, PMI if under 20% down.
FHA Loans: Government-backed, as low as 3.5% down, 580+ credit, ideal for first-time buyers.

highlightBox.text: � Special programs exist for veterans (VA loans) and rural buyers (USDA loans)‚Äîboth offer 0% down options.

leftPanel.title: Understanding PITI Payments
paragraphs: Your total monthly mortgage payment includes four components‚ÄîPITI:

infoCard.title: Fixed vs. Adjustable:
items: Fixed: Same rate forever, predictable payments
ARM: Lower initial rate, then adjusts
5/1 ARM = fixed for 5 years, then adjusts annually
ARMs carry risk if rates rise significantly

leftPanel.title: What You'll Pay Before Moving In
paragraphs: The purchase price is just the beginning. Upfront costs total 5-25% of the home price depending on your down payment.

layoutData.title: Monthly and Annual Costs Beyond the Mortgage
paragraphs: Your mortgage payment is just one piece. Budget for all these ongoing expenses to understand your true housing cost.
bulletPoints: Property Taxes: 0.5-2.5% of home value annually (varies by location)
Maintenance: Budget ~1% of home value annually ($2,500 for $250K home)

keyPoint.text: üí° A common mistake: only budgeting for the mortgage. Total housing costs are typically 30-50% higher.

leftPanel.title: Financial & Lifestyle Readiness
paragraphs: Homeownership isn't right for everyone at every stage of life. Honestly assess your readiness across multiple dimensions:
Financial: Stable income, adequate savings, low debt, good credit score (620+ conventional, 580+ FHA).
Lifestyle: Plan to stay 3-5+ years, willing to handle maintenance, time for property upkeep.
Market: Interest rates, local housing prices, rent-vs-buy math in your area.

highlightBox.text: � Use the 28/36 rule: Housing costs under 28% of income, total debt under 36%.

scenario.name: The Garcias' First Home Purchase
paragraphs: David and Sofia Garcia, ages 32 and 30, saved for 4 years while renting. They purchased a ${{STATE_MEDIAN_HOME_PRICE}} home in {{STATE_NAME}} using an FHA loan with 3.5% down payment.
Their preparation: Improved credit scores from 620 to 710, paid off car loans, built emergency fund separate from down payment savings.
Monthly costs: $1,800 mortgage + $250 taxes + $125 insurance + $150 PMI + $200 maintenance = $2,525/month

layoutData.title: Myths About Buying a Home
paragraphs: Don't let common misconceptions drive your housing decisions. Get the facts before committing to one of life's biggest financial moves.
bulletPoints: "You need 20% down": Many programs allow 3-3.5% down (though you'll pay PMI)
"Buying is always better than renting": Depends on how long you stay, market conditions, opportunity cost
"Real estate always goes up": Values can and do decline‚Äîsee 2008
"Mortgage payment = housing cost": True cost includes taxes, insurance, maintenance, repairs
"Buy the most expensive home you qualify for": Being house-poor leaves no room for other goals
"Renting is throwing money away": Renting provides flexibility and frees capital for other investments
